questions.question: A urologist is teaching medical students about the causes of hydronephrosis. When discussing bilateral hydronephrosis, which of the following conditions is not typically associated with this presentation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Retrocaval ureter Explanation: Retrocaval ureter is not associated with bilateral hydronephrosis. It is associated with unilateral hydronephrosis. Unilateral Hydronephrosis Bilateral Hydronephrosis Extramural Causes: Advanced Malignancies Colorectal cancer Carcinoma cervix Carcinoma Prostate Retroperitoneal fibrosis Retrocaval Ureter (Option D) Congenital Causes: Posterior Urethral Valve (Option C ruled out) Urethral atresia Intramural Causes: PUJ Obstruction Ureterocele Ureteric Stricture Urothelial tumor Acquired Causes: Bladder neck stenosis (Option A ruled out) BPH (Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia) (Option B ruled out) CA Prostate Urethral strictures Intraluminal Causes: Stone Papillary Slough Due to: Analgesic nephropathy Sickle cell anemia Reference: SRB Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 1000, 1001

questions.question: A male presents with a 3 cm stone in the middle calyx of the left kidney. Which of the following statements regarding the use of percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) in the management of this patient is correct? ESWL several days postoperatively urinary tract

options.A: PCNL involves creating a large flank incision to directly access the renal pelvis and remove the stone
options.B: PCNL is indicated for the treatment of renal stones larger than 2 cm in diameter or stones resistant to
options.C: PCNL is performed under general anesthesia, and the patient is required to remain immobilized for
options.D: PCNL is contraindicated in patients with severe hydronephrosis or anatomical abnormalities of the

questions.explanation: or stones resistant to ESWL Correct Answer: B) PCNL is indicated for the treatment of renal stones larger than 2 cm in diameter or stones resistant to ESWL Explanation: PCNL involves the creation of a small percutaneous tract through the skin, directly accessing the renal collecting system and is indicated for the treatment of renal stones larger than 2 cm in diameter or stones resistant to ESWL. Typically, this procedure is done in the prone position. Fluoroscopy or ultrasound is used for localisation. The posterolateral calyx is commonly chosen for entry. Principle of PCNL: PCNL involves the creation of a small percutaneous tract through the skin, directly accessing the renal collecting system. (Option A ruled out) Using this tract, the surgeon can then remove the stone using various instruments, such as forceps, baskets, or ultrasonic or pneumatic lithotripters. Indications for PCNL: Renal stones larger than 2 cm in diameter Stones resistant to or unsuitable for extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) Stones in anomalous kidneys or in the setting of previous failed stone treatment (Option D ruled out) PCNL is typically performed under general anesthesia and the patient is generally encouraged to ambulate soon after the procedure. (Option C ruled out) Complications : include bleeding, infection and pleural violation in cases of supracostal puncture. Severe bleeding may require selective angioembolization. Contraindications to percutaneous nephrolithotomy: Pregnancy. Untreated UTI. Bleeding diathesis. Current anticoagulation.

questions.question: In a 55-year-old male with sterile pyuria, flank pain, and a "moth-eaten" renal calyx appearance on CT, which test is the gold standard for confirming genitourinary tuberculosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Urine Culture & Sensitivity Genitourinary tuberculosis (GUTB) often presents with sterile pyuria , hematuria, and imaging features such as moth-eaten calyces . The gold standard for diagnosis is urine culture for Mycobacterium tuberculosis using 3 early-morning urine samples , as it confirms the presence of active infection. It is more specific than imaging and functional studies. Genitourinary Tuberculosis (GUTB) Feature Details Common symptoms Flank pain, dysuria, sterile pyuria, hematuria Key imaging findings Moth-eaten calyces, cortical scarring, shrunken kidney Gold standard diagnostic test Urine culture for M. tuberculosis (three early-morning samples) Other helpful tests PCR for TB, CT urogram, IVP for structural changes Typical CT/IVP appearance Irregular calyces, calcification, strictures, non-functioning kidney Retrograde Pyelogram (Option A): Incorrect because it shows structural abnormalities but does not confirm infection etiology , especially early in disease. Intravenous Pyelogram (Option C): Incorrect because while it shows the classic ‘moth-eaten’ appearance, it is not confirmatory —used more for evaluation than diagnosis. Contrast-Enhanced CT (Option D): Incorrect because though helpful for structural and functional assessment, it does not confirm the specific diagnosis of tuberculosis. Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1472, 1473

questions.question: A 45-year-old man with a history of renal tuberculosis presents with increased urinary frequency and lower abdominal discomfort that has gradually worsened over the past few months. Imaging studies reveal significant fibrosis and a reduced bladder size. Which of the following features is present in the advanced stage, where the bladder is contracted?

options.A: Golf hole around the ureteric orifice
options.C: The beaded appearance of the distal ureter

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Golf hole around the ureteric orifice Explanation: The patient's history of renal tuberculosis with current symptoms and imaging findings, aligns most closely with Genitourinary Tuberculosis (GUTB) as the underlying cause of her bladder issues. In advanced cases, where the bladder is contracted, the ureteric orifices may appear as a "golf hole". Bladder TB: Infection Progression: The infection spreads from the ureter into the bladder, with an early sign observable during cystoscopy being pallor around the ureteric orifice in the bladder. Chronic Inflammation: This inflammation leads to the formation of tubercles in the bladder, followed by fibrosis. Bladder Changes: The fibrosis results in a small, contracted bladder with significantly reduced capacity, often referred to as a "thimble bladder." Advanced TB: In advanced cases, where the bladder is contracted, the ureteric orifices may appear as "golf hole" shapes. (Option A) GUTB involving the prostate: Calcification: The affected area becomes calcified, resulting in a hard and nodular texture. (Option B ruled out) Testis: The testis is usually spared in cases of genitourinary tuberculosis. Characteristic Feature: A distinctive feature of tuberculosis is the "beaded" appearance of the vas deferens, often accompanied by multiple discharging sinuses through the scrotum. (Option C ruled out)

questions.question: A 38-year-old male with a history of untreated pulmonary tuberculosis presents with symptoms of dysuria, hematuria, and flank pain, and noticed a gradual worsening of his symptoms. His laboratory tests are consistent with renal impairment. Which of the following features are seen in this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All of the above Explanation: GUTB (Genitourinary TB) typically originates from the hematogenous spread of Mycobacterium tuberculosis from the lungs or thoracic lymph nodes. The bacteria lodge in the kidneys, triggering an inflammatory response causing tissue destruction, caseous necrosis, dystrophic calcification granuloma formation, and scarring and strictures in the ureter. The putty kidney is a sequela of genitourinary tuberculosis (GUTB) characterized by "extensive dystrophic calcification involving all or most of the kidney, seen as calcified non-functioning renal tissue. " It is the end stage of renal tuberculosis making the kidney non-functioning. Hematogenous spread and granuloma formation: GUTB typically originates from hematogenous spread of Mycobacterium tuberculosis from the lungs or thoracic lymph nodes. The bacteria lodge in the kidneys, triggering an inflammatory response that leads to the formation of granulomas. Caseous necrosis and tissue destruction : If the infection progresses, it can lead to caseous necrosis, a form of cell death

questions.question: A 35-year-old man presents with intermittent right flank pain and a palpable mass in his right loin. His urinalysis shows microscopic hematuria. Imaging reveals the presence of unilateral hydronephrosis. Which of the following correctly describes the condition known as Dietl's crisis? urine

options.A: Sudden onset of flank pain accompanied by fever and pyuria
options.B: Intermittent flank pain with a palpable abdominal mass that resolves after voiding large volume of
options.C: Constant dull ache in the loin with progressive renal failure
options.D: Acute anuria associated with bilateral ureteric obstruction

questions.explanation: voiding large volume of urine Correct Answer: B) Intermittent flank pain with a palpable abdominal mass that resolves after voiding a large volume of urine Explanation: Dietl’s crisis is seen in patients with unilateral hydronephrosis . Key components of Dietl's crisis include: Intermittent or acute attacks of renal colic (flank pain) Swelling or mass in the loin (palpable abdominal mass) Resolution of symptoms after passing a large volume of urine Unilateral Hydronephrosis Bilateral Hydronephrosis Congenital PUJ obstruction and calculus are the most common causes Male to Female ratio 2:1 Right side kidney is affected more commonly From lower urinary tract obstruction: Loin pain Features of bladder outlet obstruction—frequency, hesitancy, poor stream Kidneys are not palpable if renal failure develops early Dull aching loin pain with dragging sensation or heaviness Mass in the loin which moves with respiration Dietl's crisis (Intermittent Hydronephrosis) : Swelling in the loin after acute renal colic, disappears after passing a large volume of urine (Option B) Dysuria, haematuria. If infected, fever and tenderness in the renal angle From bilateral upper urinary tract obstruction: Loin pain, mass in the loin, attacks of renal colic In severe cases, features of renal failure like oliguria, edema, and hiccoughs may be present Reference: SRB Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 1002

questions.question: A 62-year-old diabetic man presents with fever, flank pain, and a palpable mass in his left loin. Initial ultrasound reveals a fluid collection associated with the left kidney. Which of the following statements is incorrect with respect to the probable diagnosis of this patient?

options.A: Pyonephrosis is commonly seen in patients with hydronephrosis due to renal obstruction
options.B: Pyonephrosis can spread by cortical extension & hematogenous route
options.C: Pyonephrosis involves the collection of pus inside the kidney
options.D: Percutaneous nephrostomy is the treatment of choice for elderly and diabetic patients

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Pyonephrosis can spread by cortical extension & hematogenous route inside the kidney and is commonly associated with chronic obstruction, especially hydronephrosis. Cortical and hematogenous spread is seen in Perinephric abscess. Feature Pyonephrosis Perinephric Abscess Definition Destruction of renal parenchyma followed by pus collection inside kidneys (Option C ruled out) Collection of pus around the kidney Spread by 2 routes: Cortical extension and Hematogenous spread (Option B) Most Common Cause Renal stones leading to hydronephrosis (the most common cause of obstruction) (Option A ruled out) E. coli > Proteus Urine culture positive in 1/3rd of cases Blood culture positive in 50% of cases Clinical Features Fever Anemia Mass in loin Pain Tenderness in flanks Fever Diagnosis USG USG/CT Management IV antibiotics + Drainage Percutaneous nephrostomy (Elderly, diabetic, etc) (Option D ruled out) For Non-Functioning Kidney: Nephrectomy IV antibiotics + percutaneous drainage If the patient does not respond after percutaneous drainage, then go for Open drainage / Nephrectomy Reference: SRB Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 1004, 1005

questions.question: A 55-year-old female with poorly controlled diabetes presents with fever, flank pain, and vomiting. Initial investigations reveal a kidney infection. Which of the following findings is likely to be seen in Emphysematous Pyelonephritis but not in Xanthogranulomatous Pyelonephritis?

options.A: Presence of Proteus as the causative organism
options.B: Air within the kidney or perinephric region on imaging
options.D: Foamy lipid-laden histiocytes in renal parenchyma

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Air within the kidney or perinephric region on imaging Explanation: Emphysematous Pyelonephritis is characterized by the presence of air around the kidney (perinephric region) or within the kidney itself. This is a key distinguishing feature visible on X-ray. CT scan is the investigation of choice for confirming this finding. Emphysematous Pyelonephritis Xanthogranulomatous Pyelonephritis Definition Presence of air around the kidney or within the kidney (Option B) Chronic bacterial infection Causative Organism E. coli, Klebsiella Proteus (most common) (Option A ruled out) Associations Diabetes (due to low immunity), Female gender Associated with Struvite stones (Option C ruled out) Clinical Features Flank pain, Fever, Vomiting Flank pain, Fever with chills and rigor, Flank Mass, Bacteriuria Investigation of Choice CT scan CECT (Bear’s paw sign) Findings The presence of air in renal parenchyma and parenchyma of surrounding structures Presence of Xanthoma cells in renal parenchyma (Foamy lipid-laden histiocytes) (Option D ruled out) Mimics Clear cell variant of RCC Treatment IV antibiotics Resuscitation Control blood glucose Percutaneous drainage if urinary tract obstruction is present Nephrectomy Initially, Partial Nephrectomy If not possible, total Nephrectomy Image This computed tomography (CT) scan demonstrates extensive destruction of the right kidney with intraparenchymal gas on the right, obliterating the renal architecture. The left kidney is normal. Xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis with the ‘bear’s paw sign’

questions.question: A 60-year-old patient with a history of recurrent renal stones is scheduled for laser-based intracorporeal lithotripsy to treat a 2 cm stone in the renal pelvis. Which of the following lasers is most commonly used for intracorporeal lithotripsy procedures?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Holmium: YAG laser Explanation: The Holmium: YAG laser is the most commonly used laser for intracorporeal lithotripsy as it is highly effective in fragmenting stones and is widely used for treating both renal and ureteral stones. Types of Intracorporeal Lithotripsy Description Laser Lithotripsy Holmium: YAG laser Used in Renal stones and BPH Stone vaporization by photo-thermal mechanism Costly but safe Electrohydraulic Lithotripsy (EHL) Cheap but low safety margin Mainly used for bladder stones Ultrasonic Lithotripsy Not commonly used Ballistic Lithotripsy Not commonly used Carbon dioxide laser (Option C): It was used earlier for lithotripsy, but not popular anymore for lithotripsy with the advancement in lesser complication technologies. It is the treatment of choice for condylomata acuminata that are extensive or recurrent. Neodymium: YAG laser (Option B): Holmium: YAG laser is superior to Neodymium: YAG laser as it provides tissue cutting and coagulative hemostasis in a single device. Helium laser (Option D): They are not suitable for treating renal/ureteric stones because energy is emitted in a continuous mode and severe heat is generated that can damage the tissues. Reference: Campbell Walsh Textbook of Urology, 12th Edition, Page 1170-1174 Lasers for the treatment of urinary stone disease - PMC Use of the CO2 laser in urology

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common type of radiolucent renal stone?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Uric Acid Stones Explanation: Radiopaque stones: Calcium Oxalate Stones (Option A ruled out) Calcium Phosphate Stones Struvite Stones Cystine stones are also mildly radiopaque (Option C ruled out) Radiolucent stones include: Uric acid stones (most common) (Option B) Xanthine stones (rarely seen, mainly in patients with xanthinuria) (Option D ruled out) Stone Type Features Image Calcium Oxalate The most common type of stone (60–85% of all stones) ; Radiopaque Associated with hypercalciuria, hypercalcaemia, hyperoxaluria, hyperuricosuria, and hypocitraturia Types: monohydrate (dumbbell shaped) , dihydrate (envelope shaped) Calcium Phosphate Pure calcium phosphate stones are rare Types include apatite and brushite stones Apatite stones are seen with infection; brushite stones are associated with distal renal tubular acidosis Struvite Aka staghorn calculi / Triple phosphate stone (Ca, Mg, NH4+, Phosphate) Radiopaque Infection stones that form in alkaline urine due to urease-producing bacteria (e.g., Proteus, Klebsiella, Serratia, Enterobacter ) Cystine Radiopaque , Constitute approximately 1% of stones Result from cystinuria , an autosomal recessive inherited disease that causes decreased reabsorption of cystine Very hard stones due to disulfide bonds Uric Acid Radiolucent Promoted by hyperuricosuria, which can be caused by conditions like gout and myeloproliferative disorders Precipitates in acidic urine and remains soluble in alkaline urine

questions.question: A male underwent ESWL for a 2 cm renal stone 4 weeks ago. Imaging now reveals multiple small stone fragments (street of stone) in the ureter. Which of the following statements regarding the management of this condition is correct?

options.A: Urgent ureteroscopy should be performed to remove the obstructing stone fragments
options.B: Conservative management with alpha-blocker therapy is the first-line approach
options.C: Repeat ESWL is the preferred option to further fragment the retained stone pieces
options.D: Percutaneous nephrolithotomy is the treatment of choice to clear the Steinstrasse

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Conservative management with alpha-blocker therapy is the first-line approach ESWL. In this case, with no obstruction, the initial approach should be conservative. It is a common complication, occurring in up to 15-20% of cases. The management of Steinstrasse depends on the severity of symptoms and the degree of obstruction. In this case, with intermittent symptoms and no complete obstruction, the initial approach should be conservative. This includes: Increased fluid intake to promote stone fragment passage Administration of alpha-blockers (e.g., tamsulosin) to facilitate ureteric relaxation and stone passage (Option B) Close monitoring with periodic imaging to assess the progress of stone passage If the conservative approach is unsuccessful or the patient develops severe symptoms or complete obstruction, then more invasive interventions, such as ureteroscopy (Option A ruled out) or percutaneous nephrolithotomy (Option D ruled out) , may be considered. Repeat ESWL is the preferred option to further fragment the retained stone pieces (Option C): Steinstrasse is a result of the initial ESWL, and further ESWL may not be effective in clearing the fragments and could potentially worsen the condition.

questions.question: A male presents with a 10 mm stone in the lower pole of the left kidney. Regarding the use of extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) for this patient, which of the following statements is false? passage

options.A: ESWL works by generating focused shock waves that pass through the body and fragment the stone
options.B: ESWL is contraindicated in patients with significant skeletal deformities or obesity
options.C: ESWL can be performed on stones less than 2 cm in diameter for optimal fragmentation
options.D: Post-ESWL, the patient is encouraged to ambulate soon after the procedure to facilitate stone

questions.explanation: fragmentation Correct Answer: C) ESWL can be performed on stones less than 2 cm in diameter for optimal fragmentation Explanation: While smaller stones (typically less than 2 cm) generally respond better to extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL), the procedure can be performed on stones up to 3-4 cm in diameter with appropriate patient selection and treatment parameters. Principles of Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy (ESWL): Shock Wave Generation: (Option A ruled out) ESWL utilizes high-energy shock waves generated outside the body. These shock waves are focused on the location of the stone using imaging guidance (e.g., ultrasound, fluoroscopy). Stone Fragmentation: The focused shock waves create a rapid change in pressure at the stone's surface. This pressure change causes the stone to fracture into smaller fragments. Indications for ESWL: Radiolucent or radiopaque renal or ureteric stones less than 2 cm in diameter Stones located in the renal pelvis, upper, or middle ureter Patients with normal renal function and no severe hydronephrosis Contraindications to ESWL: Pregnancy Bleeding disorders or anticoagulant therapy Uncontrolled urinary tract infection Severe skeletal deformities or obesity (Option B ruled out) Distal ureteric obstruction Solitary kidney or severe renal impairment Patients are generally encouraged to ambulate soon after ESWL to facilitate the passage of the fragmented stones. (Option D ruled out)

questions.question: A male presents with a 5 mm lower-ureteric stone and no hydronephrosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management strategy for this patient?

options.D: Trial of conservative management with medical expulsive therapy

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Trial of conservative management with medical expulsive therapy Explanation: Indications for conservative management of renal stones: Upto 5 mm in size Non dilated ureter Stone located in the lower third of the ureter Progressive downward movement on repeated scan The conservative management strategy includes: Increased fluid intake to promote diuresis and stone passage Medical expulsive therapy with alpha-blockers or calcium channel blockers Regular follow-up with imaging to monitor stone location and size Intervention (e.g., ureteroscopy, SWL) if the stone fails to pass or symptoms worsen Medical expulsive therapy (MET) for conservative management: Involves the use of alpha-blocker medications (e.g., tamsulosin) or calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine) Helps to relax the ureter smooth muscle, facilitating the spontaneous passage of the stone Typically recommended for stones up to 10 mm in size, with a success rate of 50-80% In cases where conservative management with MET fails or is not appropriate, other interventional options may be considered, such as: Ureteroscopic stone extraction (Option A ruled out) ESWL (for more distal ureteric stones or renal stones) (Option B ruled out) Percutaneous nephrolithotomy (for large or complex renal stones) (Option C ruled out) Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1476

questions.question: A 30 years old male presents with recurrent episodes of right flank pain and hematuria. Ultrasonography and plain abdominal radiography are inconclusive for renal stones. Which of the following statements regarding the use of radionuclide scans in the evaluation of this patient is correct? stones stones

options.A: Technetium-99m dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) scan is the preferred modality to diagnose renal
options.B: Gallium-67 citrate scan has higher sensitivity and specificity than DMSA scan for detecting renal
options.C: Radionuclide scans are exclusively reserved for patients with impaired renal function
options.D: Radionuclide scans can distinguish between obstructing and non-obstructing renal stones

questions.explanation: renal stones Correct Answer: D) Radionuclide scans can distinguish between obstructing and non-obstructing renal stones Explanation: Radionuclide scans can distinguish between obstructing and non-obstructing renal stones. Radionuclide scans, such as technetium- 99m mercaptoacetyltriglycine (MAG3) or diethylenetriaminepentaacetic acid (DTPA) scans, are useful in the evaluation of renal stones when other imaging modalities are inconclusive. Radionuclide scans assess renal function and the degree of obstruction, which can help differentiate between obstructing and non-obstructing stones. Obstructing stones will typically show delayed or decreased tracer accumulation in the affected kidney, indicating impaired drainage. Non-obstructing stones may not cause significant changes in the radionucleotide scan. Radionuclide scans are especially helpful in patients with inconclusive findings on ultrasonography or plain radiography, as well as in those with impaired renal function. Radionuclide scans are more sensitive than intravenous pyelography (IVP) in detecting obstruction and can provide valuable information on renal function. Technetium-99m dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) scan is the preferred modality to diagnose renal stones (Option A): DMSA scans are used to evaluate renal parenchymal abnormalities, such as renal scarring. They are not the preferred modality for diagnosing renal stones. Gallium-67 citrate scan has higher sensitivity and specificity than DMSA scan for detecting renal stones (Option B): Gallium-67 citrate scans are more commonly used for the detection of certain infections and malignancies. Radionuclide scans are exclusively reserved for patients with impaired renal function (Option C): While radionuclide scans can be particularly useful in patients with impaired renal function, they are not exclusively reserved for these patients . They can also be used in patients with normal renal function when other imaging modalities are inconclusive Reference: Nuclear Renal Scan - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.question: Which of the following investigations is considered the gold standard for diagnosing renal stones and can identify both radiopaque and radiolucent stones?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Non-contrast computed tomography (NCCT) Explanation: Non-contrast computed tomography (NCCT) is considered the gold standard for diagnosing renal stones. NCCT scans provide detailed images of the urinary tract and can identify both radiopaque (visible on X-rays) and radiolucent (not easily visible on X-rays) stones. Investigations for renal stones: Urinalysis: This is often the initial investigation performed. It can reveal the presence of blood (hematuria), white blood cells (pyuria), and crystals in the urine, all suggestive of a possible stone. The pH of the urine can also give clues about the type of stone. Kidney, Ureter, and Bladder (KUB) X-ray : It can detect some types of stones, particularly calcium-containing stones, which appear opaque on X-rays. (Option A ruled out) Ultrasound : It's particularly useful for detecting hydronephrosis (swelling of the kidney due to urine blockage) caused by stones and can be helpful during pregnancy when minimizing radiation exposure is important. (Option B ruled out) Intravenous urogram (IVU): It involves injecting a contrast dye into a vein. The dye travels through the bloodstream to the kidneys, where it is filtered and excreted in the urine. X-rays are taken as the dye passes through the urinary tract, outlining the kidneys, ureters, and bladder. This test can reveal blockages in the urinary tract caused by stones. (Option D ruled out) Reference: Bailey and Love Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1467, 1475, 1469

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman presents with recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs), persistent back pain, and hematuria. Imaging reveals a large, branched stone occupying a significant portion of her right kidney. Urinalysis shows alkaline pH, the presence of bacteria, and crystals as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely composition of this stone?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Struvite Explanation: Struvite (Magnesium Ammonium Phosphate): Found only in alkaline urine. Appears as coffin-lid-shaped crystals and is always associated with urinary infections. Calcium Oxalate (Option A ruled out): Shapes include envelopes, spindles, ovals, octahedral, picket fences, or dumbbell-shaped. Often feature an "X" in the center. Calcium Phosphate: Colorless crystals that appear as plates, stars, stellate shapes, or clusters of needles or rosettes. Typically found in more alkaline urine. Cystine (Option D ruled out): Crystals are hexagonal in shape and resemble nearly perfect benzene rings under the microscope. Uric Acid (Option B ruled out): Crystals can be rhomboidal-shaped, rosettes, or plates. Found in acidic urine with a pH of 5.5 or lower.

questions.question: A 42-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain. Imaging reveals that he has a renal stone lodged in the middle third of his ureter. He describes the pain as radiating to his hypogastrium. Which nerve is responsible for the radiation of pain to the hypogastrium?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Iliohypogastric Nerve Explanation: The iliohypogastric nerve is responsible for sensation in the iliac fossa, hypogastrium, and groin area. It mediates the pain radiation from stones located in the middle third of the ureter . Clinical features of renal stones: Abdominal pain: Most common presentation Hematuria : Presence of blood in the urine, which can be visible (gross hematuria) or detected only under a microscope (microscopic hematuria). Urinary Symptoms : Dysuria Frequency Urgency Nocturia Nausea and Vomiting Causes of pain in renal stones: Obstruction: Causes stretching of the renal capsule, leading to non-colicky abdominal pain. Stone fragment in ureter: Causes hyperperistalsis of the ureter, resulting in colicky pain. Pain radiation: Depends on the location of the stone. Upper 1/3 of the ureter: Testis in males. Labia majora in females. Middle 1/3 of the ureter: Iliac fossa, hypogastrium, and groin (via the iliohypogastric nerve). On the right side , this pain can mimic acute appendicitis as it radiates to the right iliac fossa. On the left side , this pain can mimic diverticulitis as it radiates to the left iliac fossa. Lower 1/3 of the Ureter: Scrotum, perineum, and the inner aspect of the thigh ( via the ilioinguinal nerve) . Reference: Bailey and Love Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1475-1476

questions.question: A 50-year-old man with a history of HIV, on ART, presents to the emergency department with severe flank pain, hematuria, and difficulty urinating. Recent imaging studies reveal the presence of renal stones. Which of the following ART drugs is commonly associated with the development of renal stones?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Indinavir Explanation: Indinavir is a protease inhibitor that has proven highly effective in boosting CD4+ cell counts and reducing HIV-RNA levels in patients with HIV and AIDS. However, patients taking indinavir are at a notable risk of developing urolithiasis. Drug-induced stones: Triamterene: Excessive use of this potassium-sparing diuretic can lead to the formation of radiolucent stones. Indinavir: This protease inhibitor used in HIV treatment can also cause the formation of radiolucent stones. Silicate Stones: These stones can form due to excessive consumption of antacids containing silica. Radiolucent Stones caused by: (mnemonic: TIXU) T – Triamterene I – Indinavir X – Xanthine U – Uric acid Efavirenz (Option B) and Nevirapine (Option C) : They are a component of the ART (Antiretroviral therapy) regimen and are not known to be involved in the formation of renal stones. Reference: Indinavir urolithiasis Triamterene nephrolithiasis
